author: moors
title: The Power of Sovereignty at Birth
description: Government issued birth documentation limits a newborns potential

f6_assessments.q0: I appreciate the idea here, that self-sovereign governance can begin with parents embracing the dynamic at the birth of their children.  It brings up additional insights for the importance of witnesses to a birth, or evidence of a birth, and what we accept as validation of a new human life, outside the life itself.  As a stepping stone for SSI, having such a reference immutably on the blockchain makes it easier to imagine the first identity documents the child may require as being verifiable, so I would have liked to have seen here more information on the trust registry that would be used here to authenticate and make available this record in the DAO, presumably as a DAO membership protocol (would it be regional, as governments are now?  Global for all of humanity?  Hyper-local or family oriented?).  Also, as a nascent SSI initiative, I would have liked to seen more details on what could be issued by the DAO, particularly some sort of concept of Issuing a live birth verified credential.  I suspect that is the idea here (though the proposer does mention issuing paper documents), but it should be made clearer if so.  Additionally there was some confusion around the issuing of passports...I assume they mean copies of passports, or verification of passports, not some sort of VC that originates from the DAO.
f6_assessments.q1: We will need more team information for this for sure, along with the principals of the DAO formation.  Unfortunately it doesn't look like the proposer was able to completely finish the proposal, so there is no timeline to establish the milestones and deliverables, but we can isolate some things like the creation of the DAO and the trust registry associated with validating claims.  The trust registry, in particular would be good to see fleshed out and really thought through.  It doesn't need to be fully defined, but knowing things like which protocols it would ensure (Issuance requirements, such as affidavits or witness testimony, or certification such as birth records etc.), how it would establish membership (is it a membership of issuers, holders, or both?  How are these populations represented in DAO governance?).  The team did manage to get the budget broken down, and a few entries get me thinking about how much more they really needed to describe here.  For example, I pointed out the passport issue above, but they have a budget item for a "Travel Law Researcher", which indicates they may have bigger plans for the DAO (and with the travesties regarding displaced peoples, I am all for solutions in this area).  All in all, I would have liked to have seen a lot of the missing information.
f6_assessments.q2: While no detail were included for auditability, there are a number of relevant KPIs that could have been chosen:  number of live births recorded to the DAO, milestones like issuance of governance tokens or institution of the governance framework by the DAO, onboarding of research participants (training expectant families).  For something like this, I highly recommend opensource repos for the governance of the DAO, which makes it both scalable and easy for the community to follow.  As a complete proposal, I think this idea has some real potential, and I encourage the proposer to keep building with an eye on the trust registry/governance framework.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of ​​the proposal is to build a certificate of birth identity on the Cardano blockchain through a DAO. A breakthrough idea in identity recognition, which has a huge impact on the way society operates today. Firstly, it will have a huge impact on the paperwork process, eliminating complicated procedures in some countries. There will be no more images of people having to wait in long lines for their turn or running around organizations to get birth certificates. Secondly, it will be very useful to provide the birth certificate (and later other documents such as passport, visa, household registration book, etc.) in a convenient way. This will come in handy for the homeless, who lack the ability to verify their identity at all except for an ID card - it's going to be tough if they lose this card.
So the proposal is suitable for the challenge "Self-Sovereign Identity" presented.
f6_assessments.q1:
There will be many reasons we need to discuss here to evaluate the feasibility of the proposal:

1. The recognition of birth certificates on blockchain requires the approval of many countries around the world. This is covered in the risks and challenges section but it is suggested that additional solutions should be added to address this challenge (which I think is very difficult because it belongs to the country level)
2. How can the witness groups in the DAO remotely certify that the information that users submit to the blockchain is correct or not? This has not been mentioned by the proposer.
3. In the budget breakdown, most of the budget is used for research and website building => the proposal only stops at the idea, there is no solution to this problem.
4. roadmap has not been built. I recommend that the team recommend adding this section so that the community advisor can give you more specific suggestions on the solution.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer should add more information about each member and work experience so that the community can accurately assess the transparency and searchability of the project.
The proposer adds measurement criteria and KPIs to the proposal. This is very important information in a proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal to create a borderless passport is a great idea shared by many. This proposal however does not address the fundamental issue, which is that passports are legal documents, and there is no discussion on how this blockchain based DAO passport would become a legal document, or accepted by any governments as a valid passport. It's not clear if this proposal is funded, if this would become a research project, or a functioning usable product, or both. It's not clear how building this will add value to the cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1:
Given the plan presented, and the listed qualifications of the proposer, it is unlikely this funded proposal can overcome the legal obstacles preventing this idea from becoming a reality. The proposer acknowledges the main risk of this endeavour, which is "Recognition from other countries to accept the passport" yet there is no discussion about how the proposer will get this DOA or passport to be recognized as a legal document by other countries.
There is a budget breakdown, but it is not clear who will be executing the tasks listed, or if the proposer will be able to hire and manage a qualified team to execute on the proposals goals.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no information given regarding the audibility of this proposal. 
CA's would like to see:

A roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement.
Metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal.
Clear understandable description of the targeted problem.
Clear understandable solution that addresses the problem.
A way for the community to track and evaluate the success of the proposal

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer has identified a problem and a solution to the problem but, it seems that the proposal doesn't have a real use case. Blockchain passports without borders - what is the purpose of creating such thing? Travelling around the world requires other types of IDs, all issued by centralized government entities. If anyone of us could create some "proof of anything" without peer review there will be no real value to store for posterity.
f6_assessments.q1:
It is unclear what is the area of expertize of the proposer as there aren't any references about it.

The budget is broken down into identifiable items but it seems that there are some miscalculations ("Community Manager = $300/wk" - for how many weeks?). Also it is unclear what is the cost for the Dapp developing stage.

The plan doesn't describe the resources necessary to implement the proposal. (human and other types)

There is no roadmap with milestones for the project (what is to be done and how it is done?)
f6_assessments.q2:
There are no KPI/metrics defined to measure the success of the proposal.

As it is, the proposal lacks in providing essential and relevant info for a successful implementation so it is highly unlikely to succeed.
